body:
I discussed with xqdan, and I think maybe we can enhance the storage_rewrite step by step. Maybe we can just update it to support case like:
`a[100]` is `float32` with length 100, `b[200]` if `float16` with length 200 , but `a` and `b` can use one buffer with size 100 * 32 bit.
so the rule is, a buffer (`A`) can merge any buffer which total size is equal to A.total_size

Can you try to see if we can run the resnet on webGL rpc? The only thing that we have to do likely, is to include graph_runtime.cc in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/src/runtime/graph into web runtime

has fixed offset when reusing different type buffer. please review @tqchen 
I'll send another PR for @libing4752 's comment, and for this case below
```
a[] = 1.0 (float32)
b[] = 1 (int16)
c[] = 1 (int 16)
d[] = b[] + c[]

b -> a[0] elem_offset = 0
c -> a[16] elem_offset = 16
```

The current solution is still dangerous when dtype.bytes() and elem_type.bytes() are not dividable. Say I have a float3 and another float4. The current logic will cause problem. Also note that the real number in terms of bytes can be computed by( note that we need to multiply by lanes)

```
dtype.bits() * dtype.lanes() / 8
```
See comment, just to rename the functions to make sure API is explicit in terms of its functionality

Thinking a bit more about this, maybe it makes sense to introduce a BuildConfigNode object, and use the TVM's node system to back the BuildConfig. This will make BuildConfig part of the language and can be able to run transparently on both sides. We can still add more function support to BuildConfig object on the python side such as enter and exit. If we are going to pursue that path, my previous comment can be safely ignored

Ok, for bytes calculating, i just sent  a PR to HalideIR @tqchen 
https://github.com/dmlc/HalideIR/pull/21
Let us keep the byte calculation local to the functions for now, as the logic is not that hard to write
i think it's better have some abstraction for some cases
Both ways are fine, just since we use one way for existing cases, so we keep the convention for now
@tqchen Ok I've rolled back those changes and changed BuildConfig to use the node system. The code on both the python and C++ side is exercised by existing tvm and topi python tests.

Just realised there was an issue with the previous implementation - changes to the BuildConfigNode would propagate from C++ to python, but not vice versa. I've added a function to the C API to set node attributes, and the python BuildConfig now propagates changes through to the C++ BuildConfigNode.
please fix the reported lint error
@yidawang @masahi
do ``` git submodule update --init --recursive```

I created https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/885 as a basis for what we are doing in here, to simplify the code logics. elem_offset is now changed to bits_offset so the conversions are less necessary

Let us rebase against master when that is in. Now our only question would be when to reuse across buffers. In general i think @libing4752 's idea of prioritize reuse of same size is a good one.

Tianqi,

I did it in tvm directory but nothing printed out on console. I also tried to do this in nnvm repository.

Submodule path 'tvm': checked out '3a91764ec919b7a0034e104c7fac40ed5a840d12'
Submodule path 'tvm/HalideIR': checked out 'aadbf02d6bd7a545edbf6652494a7b07a97a06c1'

Try to clone tvm from scratch with option --recursive, the key problem is still not being able to clone submodules

Actually, I indeed cloned this repository with option --recursive. 
I am building runtime library (in c++) and I am afraid I might need to do something to include dmlc to c++ library?

I am not so sure.
add the dmlc/include to the include search path of your project
it's great, ship it please

On resnet 18 benchmark, this schedule gets 16.4 msec on core i7 8700K. 
I think this is very fast.
LGTM

@yzhliu Great work. Surprised that TVM can achieve such a good performance on cpu. I'm trying to reproduce the performance on more intel CPUs. So could you send out the benchmarks of TVM and mkl-dnn and the instructions to run them? BTW, I think it would be better to give the number of TFLOPS to show the computation efficiency of each implementation. It will also help to point out the optimization potential of each implementation by the ratio of computation effiency and the hardware peak TFLOPS. Many thanks.

softmax looks much better now.
It should handle inputs of any dimension and layout.
@TaoLv Thanks for your suggestion. We are working on the benchmark numbers and will share them pretty soon.

@TaoLv We're cleaning the code and will share more results soon. 
Benchmark tool under mkldnn does not count memory-reorder time, just FYI if you are trying to reproduce the results.
Yeah! Thanks that indeed resolve the issue.
done
@DengLLy Interested in pushing a patch?
@PENGUINLIONG would you be interested in contributing a tutorial or android usage guide?
@tqchen I can try but I don't have a vulkan-capable device. My laptop is vulkan capable, so if Android emulator supports forwarding vulkan calls, I can work on this.
@tqchen please review

@yidawang @yzhliu Thanks for the information. So the mkl-dnn performance in the above table is measured including both memory reordering and convolution computation, right? It does make sense to take account of the overhead of memory reordering when measuring the performance of single operator. But if we look into a deep network in which all operators are supported by mkl-dnn, the memory reordering will only take place at the beginning and end of the computation path. So it will be a very small overhead for the whole network.

@TaoLv No. The mkl-dnn performance in the above table is measured without memory reordering, neither for TVM (for benchmark, we have the mem-reordering TVM schedule separate). So it is an apple-to-apple compare here. 

What you mentioned is super correct, we're working on removing unnecessary memory reordering computation for an e2e pass.
@yzhliu Thanks for the clarification. Now I am much more surprised by TVM's high efficiency. Really look forward to more numbers and benchmark scripts.
@tqchen ok BuildConfig is now immutable, and values are set once on construction via make.node()
@siju-samuel can you act on the lint error? You can reproduce locally by make lint
@yidawang @yzhliu please comment on when things can be merged
@tqchen We are working on further improving the performance. It should be done early next week.
has updated as your comments, @tqchen please review again
Failed to set up Android SDKs here due to poor network. I will check if there is any workaround.
try to add the tvm-path/include to your search path and include it
VGG pretrained model in gluon can be directly imported into nnvm and run. Have you tried that?
cc @DengLLy

OK I've fixed a couple of issues that came up when integrating the TOPI C++ schedules, but it should now be working. The python generic_func is still compatible with all existing usage in the python codebase.

The TOPI C++ library now registers all its schedules and dense ops through the GenericFunc registry. The Python TOPI code is configured to override all of these, so C++ clients will see the C++ schedules, and Python clients will continue to see the Python schedules as before.

No, this is not correct.

For NHWC layout, the filter layout should be [filter_height, filter_width, in_channel, num_filter].
This is necessary for vectorization to work.

Great!  we are closing to the issue now.

I think we have a conflict between NNVM convolution [InferShape](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/535d63e8faf4dfb339d91df686ccaecd3552311c/src/top/nn/convolution.cc#L33) implementation to TVM operator [implementation](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/71f1b2d76b3d30924adeb67a0221d72977946e08/topi/python/topi/nn/conv2d.py#L367) in case of NHWC.

Same Conversion function is used in NNVM for Input as well as Filter where as the expectation is different in TVM topi.

As per my model @masahi  nhwc TVM topi implementation is correct where there should be different Convert Layout Input and Filter with NHWC. 

I made corresponding changes to ConvertLayout to accept additional argument to differentiate the input (kWeight / kData) and it works fine for me. 

Will raise a PR on NNVM after my testing.

Closing this issue here with an new issue on NNVM as https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/issues/370

Siva
right, ConvertLayout in nnvm needs to be changed for NHWC layout.

Ok I've addressed those - the only thing I wasn't sure about was what the signature of operator() should look like - so I've mirrored the style of PackedFunc with invoke_packed(TVMArgs args, TVMRetValue* ret) and then a separate operator()(Args&& ...args)

Also fixed 2 issues that cropped up testing integrating this upstream:
1. WrapSchedule in topi.cc did not correctly test whether it was passed `Array<Tensor>` or just `Tensor`.
2. Added an empty exported function to TOPI so that NNVM has a cross-platform way to make sure the library has been loaded, and therefore make sure the schedules have been registered.

We don't have to unless we want to put the entire update loop as a single tvm function. Because when we build a compute, it creates a function that takes output tensor as an argument, and the result will be stored into output tensor.
@merrymercy do you think if it is possible to generalize to batch_size > 1?
It is of interest to bring it to other backends as well, so I opened an issue here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/899
@ZihengJiang @masahi @adityaatluri @Laurawly
@tqchen It depends on the GEMM implementation. Now It works well for batch size 1~32 with almost the same effective GFLOPS.
Removed the empty exported function from (2) above - that doesn't work with python. Instead NNVM can load tvm_topi.dll dynamically.
@tqchen Let's merge the current solution for now if it looks good to you.

@srkreddy1238 The C++ port does not include any convolutions, as @tqchen mentioned the convolution schedules are currently undergoing more churn than the other ones.

Has the change broken NHWC support in python, or is it just missing from the C++ port? The latter is intended, the former is definitely not.
Unless you mean with pooling/softmax ops - NHWC support for those was added to python after the C++ ops were added. I can fix that disparity up once the GenericFunc PR is resolved.

@alex-weaver do you mean I don't have to port updated python pooling and softmax to c++?

The recent nnvm calls into c++ topi for pooling and softmax. Python topi has nhwc support, while c++ topi doesn't. That is what @srkreddy1238 is mentioning.
If you are able to port them, that would be appreciated because that would let me focus on getting the C++ interface up to speed in other areas in topi, tvm and nnvm.
No problem, will be done soon.

Appreciate quick response.

I am aware of the convolution status. Current issue is about the pool ops.

@masahi: appreciate your initiative & waiting for your PR :)

Siva

Here is one thought. I'm not 100% sure I'm correct: The main problem here is that we are trying to inline a reduction computation, and that builds a computation tree that has reduction in a non-root node. Does this make sense?

I now have time to start working on the clojure exploration of this library.

I would like to begin by building out the jvm add_cpu test but completely from clojure; meaning doing the dynamic compilation step from clojure in the first place.

I have the library loading and from the python code, the first step is to create a var object.  Scanning through the python, this calls _api_internal._Var, which appears to be a function that is exported via the global function names list.

When I call Function/listGlobalFuncNames, however, I do not see *any* of the functions that should appear in the _api_internal module.  

Here is the list that I got from the list-global-func-names call:

```["tvm.graph_runtime.remote_create"
 "contrib.rpc._CreateEventDrivenServer"
 "contrib.rpc._LoadRemoteModule"
 "contrib.rpc._ModuleHandle"
 "module._RPCTimeEvaluator"
 "tvm.contrib.rpc.server.download"
 "contrib.rpc._ImportRemoteModule"
 "tvm.contrib.rpc.server.upload"
 "module.loadbinary_opencl"
 "module.loadfile_cl"
 "device_api.opencl"
 "module.loadbinary_cuda"
 "_GetDeviceAttr"
 "contrib.rpc._SessTableIndex"
 "module.loadfile_clbin"
 "__tvm_set_device"
 "module.loadfile_ptx"
 "module.loadfile_so"
 "module._GetSource"
 "module._ImportsSize"
 "module._GetSystemLib"
 "module._GetImport"
 "module._Enabled"
 "module._GetTypeKey"
 "module._LoadFromFile"
 "contrib.rpc._ServerLoop"
 "module._SaveToFile"
 "tvm.contrib.cublas.matmul"
 "module.loadfile_cubin"
 "tvm.contrib.cblas.matmul"
 "device_api.rpc"
 "device_api.cpu"
 "tvm.graph_runtime.create"
 "contrib.rpc._Connect"
 "device_api.gpu"]
```
In fact, this list seems quite small for the global names; like there is an initialization step I missed.
OK, yes you are right, reduction cannot be inline currently. It is fine to have reduction at a non-root node, but we need to use compute at at the inner most level to do so.
see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/apps/howto_deploy
see https://github.com/kripken/emscripten/pull/5589 seems has things to do with asmjs. Should work out of box if we use WASM backend
I am not sure what is happening on your side, but maybe it is related to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24298144/duplicate-symbols-for-architecture-x86-64-under-xcode?
The current set of changes looks fine. Let us proceed with next steps with testcases
fixed by #905
https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/pull/369
these are APIs for the runtime stack, which get registered by default, if we want to add compiler stack, we need to link libtvm.so instead of libtvm_runtime.so

Right, except for the part where I'm forced to use C instead of CPP and can only use a stripped down version of the runtime which doesn't include dylib loading *or* IO *or* LLVM.

I appreciate the link, but I'd also appreciate if you left the issue open so that it remains visible to someone who is more willing to answer my [albeit very specific and constrained] question.
I see, feel free to reopen the issue, we tend to close issue aggressively and only reopen when necessary

If you use can cxx, likely the deploy example serves what you need(stripped down, no dependency)

If you want to remove dynamic library loader, follow the system loader module.

If you cannot use cxx, read the cxx example and you should be able to find a C counterpart  in the API

Thanks! I'll try all of those things. There's no getting around the static linking constraint, though.
I respect that you want to keep your issue tracker clear, so I'll continue debugging today and close this issue if I can (or fail to) make progress.

In your specific code, we will need to get a correct function handle first from a TVM module,(the tvm main) handle is not by default available as a symbol. You need to retrieve it from a Module 

You can do this by either create a DSOModule, which you can do dynamic load, or get the system module(add system lib option when you build the library)

The system library module, which registers the function table to a global table works with static linking if you want to link everything together.

That cpp example shows how to retrieve the system module , although it is mixed together with the dll loading.

Feel free to keep the issue open, I just thought that answer might be suffice for fixing the issue, but we definitely want to resolve your problem :)

In short, statistically link the generated .o with your main application, use a stripped version of runtime that includes the system module support. And follow the example after GetSystemLib line in deployment example
@zhreshold can you help to provide a concrete list of operator that is needed?
Contributions are  more than welcomed

@alex-weaver I'm getting "multiple definition" link error after I upgraded tvm submodule in nnvm to the latest one. The problem seems to be that I included "tvm/reduction.h" in tvm/softmax.h, and everything is defined in the header file. 

Is this expected? Should I remove include "tvm/reduction.h" from softmax.h?
Cool, that seemed to work. Thanks for your advice and patience!
likely due to the fact that some function did not declared as inline

yes inlining everything will fix the issue, if that is the policy of C++ topi. 

Right now, reduction.h is included from two compilation units below, which causes the link error.
nnvm/src/top/nn/nn.cc 
nnvm/src/top/tensor/reduce.cc
header library should always define the functions as inline, please go ahead and send a PR to fix tihs
ok
@tqchen any other comments?
@tqchen CI is failing somehow.

As a test I changed the JNI bindings to link to the libtvm.so like you noted and was presented with a large list of functions as a result (elided, the one I was looking for was in there).  I don't know what you want to make of this but I am guessing that there are reasons the runtime was linked specifically as opposed to the compiler infrastructure.

https://github.com/tech-ascent/tvm/tree/link-compiler-into-jar

I went through the binding pathway used and am now curious why a bespoke pathway was chosen (.cc file and hand-written java files) as opposed to more automated pathways, the best of which I have found is javacpp.

I have had a lot of success (and frustrations) with javacpp in the past will attempt some javacpp bindings for this project; it appears like the c-bindings (c_runtime_api.h, c_dsl_api.h, c_backend_api.h) are sufficient to get the full functionality of the system assuming the correct shared library is linked.  The advantage of the javacpp system really is in interop between c and java; it's pointer system works well and I already have fast paths for converting i.e java float arrays into c double pointers and things like that.

By default the java binding was used to minimally deploy the workload with minimum runtime dependency, that is why a runtime API is chosen.

The current binding is designed in a way so that it can be exposed to any front end language, like python or java. If we only want to expose one type of binding, maybe we would have done it differently.

The current binding system do offers nice properties, such as data structure and callback interop. The most important thing is that it has a minimum C ABI to depend on, which makes it easier to port across compilers. The compiler API itself can be build solely on top of this runtime system without having to write any FFI functions. We have done this in python and it works great. I would highly recommend to build java binding on top of current runtime system.

Let's differentiate between building new c-functions or some c++ wrapper into the TVM system and the specific means of binding java to the *existing* exported c layer.

I completely agree that there is no need for new c-functions or any more c++ or anything like that; the C ABI is very well designed and I cannot tell you how much I appreciate that.

It is simply the means of binding to the existing C ABI that I think could be improved; the javacpp method of binding to C ABI's gives the user with a lot more flexibility and power.  

So I am not suggesting that I add any more c or c++ code; I think that your team did a fantastic job there and it obviously works from python as it is.  What I am suggesting is that using a slightly different system of exposing the C ABI to the java ecosystem leaves consumers of the library with a far more flexible system with no additional work from your team or the binding mechanism.

So, we agree on the most important thing; I see your point and I am aligned there.  I aim to show, however, that the specific means of binding to the underlying system leads to a less flexible and ultimately less powerful JVM library than if the lowest level exposure of the C-functions to java is through javacpp and then any required supporting layers are added above those.

OK, I see. I think we are open to these changes. One reason we built things on top of JNI, is to make the dependency and final jar minimum when deployed on say android devices. The initial project was written in scala and moved to java for the same reason (the result jar for the runtime is around 300K as far as i recall).

My understanding is that as long as there is a java runtime for the core API(which can be either implemented via javacpp or JNI), and everything can be built on top of them. But if there are examples of code-path that might be easier via javacpp, we are open to that option.

cc @yzhliu who is the main author of jvm package

Here is the output of auto-generating the tvm bindings for the runtime API alone:

https://gist.github.com/cnuernber/e5117d79d7290a34ed1fb78bb2294674

And here is the clojure project that will compile them assuming you follow the readme directions:

https://github.com/tech-ascent/tvm-clj

I also ran into this post when I was debugging, but as far as I can tell, I do not have -ObjC in my additional linker.

If this has anything to do with my way of writing functions?
Lint issues are fixed

Do you mean testcase(s) for my changes so far (e.g., for ArgBinder class)?
Also please note that I haven't finished autotensorize work on my branch yet. There are still some technical difficulties.
